text: today on the caucus President Obama's
challenge as he prepares to deliver a
major speech on the Middle East I know
when President Obama came here after his
election to speak and to introduce
himself and to reintroduce America to
the Arab world there was quite a bit of
anticipation to a surprising extent that
is vanished President Obama like America
itself is not very popular here there's
quite a bit of skepticism part of the
purpose of this speech is to reclaim a
bit of the narrative on the Arab Spring
you've seen a lot of violent crackdowns
from Syria to Bahrain to Yemen and and
and mr obama's response to each of these
has in effect muddied his message the
arab world much more than even a year
ago is concerned with itself there's a
sense that air people are doing it for
themselves and nowhere is that stronger
or more palpable than here in Egypt went
and more and more of a kind of shrug
towards the United States the difficulty
is the administration still argues that
you have to take each of these countries
on its own terms and that not every
country demands the same response so
there's a little bit of a paradox here
question in people's minds i think is
how will President Obama distinguish
morally between a US policy towards
Libya where the US has backed a military
involvement to try to bring down Colonel
Qaddafi and other dictatorships around
the region where dictators like Colonel
Qaddafi have used force to suppress of
peaceful protesters and possibly lost
much of the legitimacy in the United
States bin Laden remains you know a very
emotionally charged figure for so many
Americans much more so ironically than
he does in the Arab world it was notable
to me moving around Cairo that that
event didn't particularly change
perceptions of the US or President Obama
I think for most people here preoccupied
as they are with the Arab Spring Osama
bin Laden seems like if anything a kind
of echo of the past I think it's also
important for the president to lay down
a marker on the israeli-palestinian
issue he made it a major foreign policy
priority when he first came into office
to help broker a deal between Israel and
the Palestinians it remains a very
important issue with Jewish voters and I
think he wants to show that despite two
very difficult years he hasn't given up
on this and is still pushing for a
historic agreement
